'''John Altenburgh''' (born April 20, 1960, [[Wausau, Wisconsin]], United States) is an [[United States|American]] [[jazz]] and [[blues]] [[pianist]], [[composer]], [[arrangement|arranger]] and [[music producer|producer]] who has made his home in [[Mosinee, Wisconsin]].<ref name="allmusic1">{{cite web|author=Jason Ankeny |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/john-altenburgh-mn0000218271/biography |title=John Altenburgh | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref> Altenburgh studied music at the [[University of Wisconsin–Oshkosh]]. He is the founder of Altenburgh Records<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=NQgEAAAAMBAJ&printsec=frontcover&lr=&rview=1#v=onepage&q=john%20altenburgh&f=false |title=Billboard - Google Boeken |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.altenburgh.com |title=Altenburgh Records - Home |publisher=Altenburgh.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref> distributed by The Orchard<ref>{{cite web|url=http://search.theorchard.com/artist/107624/releases/john-altenburgh |title=The Orchard |publisher=Search.theorchard.com |date=2011-11-19 |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emusic.com/browse/album/all/label:141083/?sort=downloads |title=Browse Albums | Discover & Download Music |publisher=eMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref> a division of [[Sony Entertainment]] and has recorded numerous [[album]]s as a solo artist and with his blues group, [[Johnny & The MoTones]].

==Early years==
Altenburgh started playing rock music as a teenager in the late 1970s to early 1980’s, most notably with the Wisconsin rock band, Bad Habit.  During this time, he had an opportunity to sign with [[Geffen Records]], a record label that had just signed [[John Lennon]] for his comeback.  Altenburgh was writing and recording in the style of the New Wave Rock sound that was just gaining popularity at that time.  After sending Geffen a demo of recent songs he had recorded, the A&R Director at Geffen asked Altenburgh for more music.  As Altenburgh stated,  "I took the next six months writing new material.  What I didn’t realize, at that time,  is they wanted more music immediately, not in six months.  When I contacted them with my new recordings, they said I was too late, that that type of music was already predominate in the pop/rock industry.  So they didn’t sign me."  Altenburgh, discouraged over missed opportunity,  left the rock world completely.<ref name="blues1">{{cite web|last=Limnios |first=Michalis |url=http://blues.gr/profiles/blogs/interview-johnny-altenburgh-piano-sun-fame-jazz-blues |title=Pianist / agent Johnny Altenburgh talks about Sun & Fame studios, Jazz & Blues, and Wisconsin scene |publisher=Blues.Gr |date=2013-06-19 |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref>

In 1981 Altenburgh enrolled at the [[University of Wisconsin-Oshkosh]] and studied music/recording technology.  Altenburgh performed a double senior recital, performing both classical voice and classical guitar. In 1985, after college, Altenburgh returned to his hometown of [[Mosinee, Wisconsin|Mosinee]], [[Wisconsin]] and built RiverSide Productions Recording Studio. In the 1980s, Altenburgh wrote production music for such national companies as [[Ski Doo]], [[Case Corporation|JI Case]] and [[US Cellular]].<ref name="audiosparx1">{{cite web|url=http://www.audiosparx.com/JohnAltenburgh |title=John Altenburgh at AudioSparx |publisher=Audiosparx.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref>

==Solo artist==
By the late 1980s, Altenburgh recorded his first jazz album entitled ''Old City''.  With that first release in 1989, Altenburgh Records was formed. Early distributors of Altenburgh Records included; City Hall Records, MS Distributing, Twinbrook and many others. Altenburgh signed and/or recorded numerous groups/musicians throughout the United States including; [[Mike Metheny]], [[Gary Brunotte]], [[Melvin Rhyne]] and [[Rebecca Parris]].

Altenburgh followed up Old City with ''Volume 2'' in 1991 garnering much radio airplay and the song "Jim & Ellys Summer Vacation" appeared in The Italian Jazz Charts<ref>[http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:rf5Gp9Ml1xcJ:www.music-chart.info/artist/223192/John-Altenburgh+&cd=18&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us&client=firefox ]{{dead link|date=April 2014}}</ref> Altenburgh followed that up with the 1993 release of ''Generations'' which was the first of Altenburgh's albums to land in the Jazz Charts at [[CMJ]]. The 1995 release ''Heartland '95'' and the '97 release, ''Legends of Keelerville'' both landed in the [[CMJ]] Jazz Chart as well as The [[Gavin Report]] Jazz Chart.<ref name="allmusic1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americanradiohistory.com/hd2/Archive-Gavin-IDX/IDX/search.cgi?zoom_sort=0&zoom_xml=0&zoom_query=john+altenburgh&zoom_cat=-1&zoom_per_page=100 |title=SEARCH: Gavin Report |publisher=Americanradiohistory.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref>  Altenburgh produced three videos under the direction of Chris Seehafer, that were frequently aired on such National shows as [[BET|Bet]]'s Bet on Jazz {[[Centric]]}. Altenburgh began touring to support his albums performing at such venues as the Black Hill Blues & Jazz Festival, The Jazz in June Festival, The Elkhart Jazz Festival, The Miller Heritage Jazz Festival and numerous others throughout the United States, including The Big Top Chautauqua <ref>{{cite web|url=http://bigtop.org/big-top-information/some-of-our-past-performers/ |title=Some of our past performers… | Big Top Chautauqua |publisher=Bigtop.org |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref> where they were recorded live and aired nationally on Tent Shore Radio.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wtip.org/drupal/content/tent-show-radio |title=Tent Show Radio | WTIP North Shore Community Radio, Cook County, Minnesota |publisher=Wtip.org |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bigtop.org/ |title=Big Top Chautauqua | |publisher=Bigtop.org |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref>  Altenburgh continued to release jazz albums through the 1990s, including; ''Christmas at Buzz's Restaurant'' in which Altenburgh's rendition of the song, "[[Amazing Grace]]" was chosen as an archive recording in the [[Library of Congress]] music archives.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lcweb2.loc.gov/diglib/ihas/loc.natlib.grace.200039969/default.html |title=Amazing grace (Hymn) / John Altenburgh [compact disc]:Bibliographic Record Description: Performing Arts Encyclopedia, Library of Congress |publisher=Lcweb2.loc.gov |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref> also included; were the entire "Christmas at Buzz's Restaurant" and "Generations" albums.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lccn.loc.gov/2008648379 |title=Library of Congress LCCN Permalink 2008648379 |publisher=Lccn.loc.gov |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://lccn.loc.gov/2006596082 |title=Library of Congress LCCN Permalink 2006596082 |publisher=Lccn.loc.gov |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref> In 2003, Altenburgh recorded the Latin Jazz album, ''Far From River Road'', where Altenburgh abandoned the piano and returned to the Classical Guitar.  He recorded and featured himself strictly on classical/Latin guitar for an entire album.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://play.google.com/store/music/album/John_Altenburgh_Far_from_River_Road?id=B4sahvjzblh3yxd5lek5zdkei2a |title=John Altenburgh: Far from River Road - Muziek op Google Play |publisher=Play.google.com |date=2011-11-16 |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref>  Altenburgh's jazz career has been written about in the books; ''The Jazz Discography'' by Tom Lords<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lordisco.com/musicians/A7.html |title=The JAZZ Discography - by Tom Lord |publisher=Lordisco.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref> and ''Music Hounds Jazz'', The Essential Album Guide.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=3JjWAAAAMAAJ&q=john+altenburgh+music+hounds+jazz&dq=john+altenburgh+music+hounds+jazz&hl=en&sa=X&ei=l74BU7juB-ScyQHw6oHgDA&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAA |title=Music Hound Jazz - Music Hound - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref>  His blues piano playing has been written about in the book, ''Blues Pianists'' by General Books, LLC<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=sLucSQAACAAJ&dq=john+altenburgh&hl=en&sa=X&ei=DhUSU7brIOm0yAHAwoD4DQ&ved=0CD4Q6AEwAjgK |title=Blues Pianists: Wilhelm Schröter, Axel Zwingenberger, Christian Dozzler |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/blues-pianists-source-wikipedia/1118122672?ean=9781156405147 |title=Blues pianists: American blues pianists, Ike Turner, W. C. Handy, Hadda Brooks, Ray Charles, Fats Domino, Professor Longhair, Skip James |publisher=Barnesandnoble.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.booksamillion.com/product/9781156405147 |title=Blues Pianists : American Blues Pianists, Ike Turner, W. C. Handy, Hadda Brooks, Ray Charles, Fats Domino, Professor Longhair, Skip Jam |publisher=Booksamillion.com |date=1985-12-29 |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref>

==Johnny & The MoTones==
In 2004, Altenburgh loaned [[Sun Studios]], [[Memphis TN]] some antique recording devices for their museum and in appreciation, John Schorr, President of Sun Studios, offered Altenburgh to come and do a roots type of recording at the famous studio.  Altenburgh agreed and the result was the 2005 release, ''Two Hits for The Kitty "The Sun Studio Sessions."''  The album was in the World's blues chart at Roots Music Report for 18 weeks<ref name="rootsmusicreport1">[http://rootsmusicreport.com/2.0/charts/archive/ ]{{dead link|date=April 2014}}</ref> and the beginning of Altenburgh's blues group, [[Johnny & The MoTones]] was established.  To date, the group has recorded four albums, all having spent significant time in the blues charts at [[Cashbox (magazine)|Cashbox]], Roots Music Report, [[iTunes]], [[cdbaby]] and others. The group has also made many videos and documentaries about their time at Sun Studios and [[Fame Studios]], [[Muscle Shoals, AL]] where they recorded their second album entitled, ''Get Gone "The Muscle Shoals Sessions."''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wpr.org/listen/496361 |title=Listen | Wisconsin Public Radio |publisher=Wpr.org |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref>  Subsequent releases ''Nothin' To Lose'' and ''Shake It'' followed in 2010 and 2013 respectively.  Both albums spent significant time in every major blues chart and the track, "Maybe Baby" landed in the Roadhouse Blues and Boogie Top 40 Chart<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.beachshag.com/ImagesSoundsResources/Dancing%20On%20the%20Edge%20News%20V%201%20N%2017.pdf |title=Dancing on the Edge News |publisher=Beachshag.com |accessdate=2014-04-08}}</ref> as compiled by [[Cashbox (magazine)]] and beachshag.com.

The 2013 release ''Shake It'' was heard world wide on such syndicated blues shows as; 
''Blues Deluxe'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lsesshow.com/ |title=Blues Deluxe |publisher=Lsesshow.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref> ''Confessing The Blues'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.confessingtheblues.info/listen.htm |title=Listen Now |publisher=Confessingtheblues.info |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref> ''Smokestack Lightning'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smokestacklightnin.com/PlayLists/playlist671.htm |title=671 - Remembering James Brown |publisher=Smokestacklightnin.com |date=2007-03-10 |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bluesprofiles.com/Bios/Johnny%20&%20The%20MoTones.htm |title=Johnny & The MoTones |publisher=Bluesprofiles.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref> ''The Americana Music Show'' (several times),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pinterest.com/calvin27516/americana-music-show-episodes/ |title=Americana Music Show Episodes on Pinterest |publisher=Pinterest.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.americanamusicshow.com/alex-culbreth-and-the-dead-country-stars/ |title=Alex Culbreth and the Dead Country Stars |publisher=Americanamusicshow.com |date=2013-04-01 |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref> ''The House of Blues Radio Hour with'' [[Dan Aykroyd]], ''Main Street Blues''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mainstreetblues.webs.com/playlist.htm |title=Playlist - Main Street Blues |publisher=Mainstreetblues.webs.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://mainstreetblues.podomatic.com/ |title=Podcast - Main Street Blues |publisher=Mainstreetblues.podomatic.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref> and others.  It marked 
the first time that the group, not only appeared in Blues Charts but Americana Music Charts as well. The album not only had straight blues but jumped into many other musical styles. Blues Blast Magazine said, " [[Johnny & The MoTones]] come out swingin’ long and strong with their self-produced collection of soul-based swing, jump swamp and gospel blues. They want you to “Shake It,” and deliver on all counts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thebluesblast.com/Archive/BluesBlasts/2013/BluesBlast5_9_13.htm |title=Blues Blast Magazine - May 9, 2013 |publisher=Thebluesblast.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref>
Johnny & The MoTones have received international attention<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bucefalportal.com/music/23363-johnny-the-motones-shake-it-2013.html |title=Johnny & The MoTones - Shake It (2013) |publisher=Bucefalportal.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref><ref name="lahoradelblues1">{{cite web|url=http://www.lahoradelblues.com/criticasantiguas.htm |title=La Hora Del Blues |language={{es icon}} |publisher=La Hora Del Blues |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://team-hush.org/johnnythe_motonesshake_it_2013_mp3_192_kbps_notag-s-5382.ts |title=Détails pour le torrent "Johnny & The Motones - Shake It" 2013 |publisher=Team-HuSh |date=2013-07-31 |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref> as Vincente Zumel producer of ''La Hora Del Blues Show'' in Spain wrote: "Johnny & The MoTones come back again with an album full of electrifying rhythm and blues and soul. Gratifying in all senses, Johnny & The MoTones show a complete amazing credibility, engaging all listeners with a bunch of songs performed on an easygoing way, together with an amazing bite and an own personal style, which makes them look different from many of their music colleagues."<ref name="lahoradelblues1"/>  Again the group
found its way into various blues charts, including; Roots Music Report, [[Cashbox (magazine)]], [[CD Baby]], and [[iTunes]].  When asked, in an interview conducted by the Greek writer, Michael Limnios of ''Greek Blues'', "What is the philosophy of the MoTones?" Altenburgh stated; "I love exploring all music because there is good in every music genre. So for the MoTones, we have no set course. It’s obviously based in the blues but R&B/Soul/Jazz and rock rhythms will always have influence on us."<ref name="blues1"/>

==Producer==
Altenburgh is a [[Record producer|producer]] and executive producer whose credits include works by [[Mike Metheny]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mikemetheny.com/recordings.html |title=Official Website of Jazz Trumpeter |publisher=Mike Metheny |date=2013-12-02 |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref> John Greiner, [[Rebecca Parris]], The Kenny Hadley Big Band, Bob Kase, [[Gary Brunotte]], Gary Sivils, Dennis Mitcheltree, Janet Planet, Otis McLennon, Chris O'Keefe, Randy Sabien, [[Melvin Rhyne]], and many others.

Altenburgh's compositions and recordings have been used in various television and radio programs for [[theme song]]s and [[soundtrack]]s.<ref name="audiosparx1"/> Many of his recordings have appeared in various jazz and blues charts including: Roots Music Report,<ref name="rootsmusicreport1"/> CMJ, ''[[JazzTimes]]'', ''[[Cashbox (magazine)|Cashbox]]'' and others. He has appeared as a [[sideman]] on numerous other recordings.

Altenburgh is known for his work with vintage Wisconsin music and has produced and archived several projects. Altenburgh has been a contributor to the [[Sun Studio]] Museum, in [[Memphis, Tennessee]].

==Historian==
Altenburgh is a Wisconsin historian who was an adviser for the [[Marathon County Historical Museum]] exhibit, “Long Live Rock & Roll" 1999-2000.  He is a founding and current committee member of The Rock & Roll Revival Committee of Wisconsin.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/pages/Central-Wisconsin-Rock-N-Roll-Revival/177719092381171?ref=stream |title=Central Wisconsin Rock N Roll Revival |publisher=Facebook |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref>  He has on loan family Civil War artifacts for the [[Marathon County Historical Museum]]'s exhibit 'The Road to Civil War & Back:  Marathon County & Beyond, 1861 - 1865'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marathoncountyhistory.com/Exhibits.php?ContentId=28 |title=Marathon County Historical Society: Exhibits |publisher=Marathoncountyhistory.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref>  Altenburgh has also on loan, at the [[Sun Studio]] Museum,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sunstudio.com/plan-your-tour/ |title=Plan Your Tour. The Official Site for Sun Studio. The Birthplace of Rock N' Roll and Home to the "Million Dollar Quartet" - Elvis Presley, Johnny Cash, Jerry Lee Lewis, and Carl Perkins |publisher=Sunstudio.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref> [[Memphis TN]] antique recording devices from the 1950s.  In addition, Altenburgh authored the book, ''Altenburgh Family History Since 1756''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amazon.com/s?ie=UTF8&field-author=John%20G%20Altenburgh&page=1&rh=n%3A283155%2Cp_27%3AJohn%20G%20Altenburgh |title=John G Altenburgh: Books |publisher=Amazon.com |date=2009-09-09 |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref> and produced the historical video, [[Mosinee, Wisconsin|Mosinee]] [[Wisconsin]] The Jack Altenburg Film Collection.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A5OSoMQBnRc |title=Mosinee Wisconsin The Jack Altenburg Film Collection |publisher=YouTube |date=2013-11-25 |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref> A collection of films from the 1940s-1970s that explore Mosinee, WI and surrounding areas.  Altenburgh also produced the double cd set entitled; Wisconsin Rocks!  A collection of recordings from Wisconsin rock bands from the 1950s through the 1970s.  Altenburgh currently resides in the Karl Mathie House listed in the [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Marathon County, Wisconsin]].
